title-group.article-title: A computer-aided specimen design to induce shearing strain around a hole

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Monash University, Australia

author-notes.corresp: S Khoddam, Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Monash University, Room 118, Building 31, Clayton, Victoria 3800, Australia. Email: shahin.khoddam@monash.edu

abstract.p: The local torsion process which involves an axisymmetric torsional loading around the design position of a hole in a structure has recently found important applications for grain refinement in tubes and fastener holes. The specimen design is a pre-requisite for any experimental investigation of the local torsion process. The purpose of this study is to investigate a number of potential designs which enable the implementation of the local torsion. These designs include a mandrel to twist the specimen and a range of connection configurations between the mandrel and the specimen including threaded, hexagonal and spline bindings. In order to understand the process requirements and for estimating the effect of design parameters, a coupled numerical analysis of the specimen is utilized, involving a non-linear finite element analysis using Abaqus. A sequence of computational steps with different boundary conditions at the interface is devised to simulate the coupled problem. The proposed configurations are compared for their abilities to perform the local torsion and produce the shearing strain within an annular zone around the hole. This allows investigation of the effectiveness of each design for the implementation of the local torsion. The distribution of strain accumulated around the hole in the radial direction is studied after carrying out the process. Finally, a specimen–mandrel assembly design is recommended to ensure that the process can be successfully implemented.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Mechanical joints such as bolts and rivets are extensively used in structures. Such joints require the use of drilled holes. These connections are inherently vulnerable to failure due to stress concentration in the vicinity of the hole. It has been shown that a crack emanating from a fastener hole often results in the failure of components in structures. Experiments show that cold expansion (CE) of holes, which causes compressive residual stresses, is an effective approach to decrease the crack growth rate and increase the service life of fastener holes.1–4 However, there are some shortcomings associated with CE such as heterogeneous stress and strain distribution around the hole, possibility of crack initiation near ridges, sporadic tool holdup due to high levels of friction between the tool and the component and high costs associated with replacement of tools for some specific processes.5

An alternative reinforcement method is severe plastic deformation (SPD) processing which refines grains and microstructural features through plastically deforming materials to very large strains.6 SPD processes produce large and bulk components, but in general, they are not designed for local strengthening of the material.7 Local reinforcement techniques are therefore desirable for some applications including, but not limited to, fastener holes in order to enhance mechanical properties of the material locally where it is required. These techniques involve less energy consumption and cost compared with bulk grain refinement methods. A number of SPD processes for local improvement of materials on their surfaces8 or creation of a gradient of grain refinement9,10 have been proposed recently.

Analytical studies of twisting of a hole date back to works that investigated the elastic–perfectly plastic and rigid-plastic response of an infinite disc with a circular hole loaded by pressure and twisting along the interior surface of the hole.11,12 These works presented analytical solutions with some limitations such as uniform torsional loading on the surface of the hole, the need for a previous knowledge of the materials parameters under plastic deformation and assuming a non-uniform thickness of the disc in Chern and Nemat-Nasser.12 More importantly, these works did not deal with the experimental implementation of the process. In another study, a limit analysis solution of an axially symmetric plane strain hole twisting problem was presented in which a rigid perfectly plastic material was assumed.13 However, the solution was limited to the case of a plane strain process with no reference to experimental implementation of the process.

In an early investigation, Leckie14 attempted to determine the constitutive characteristics of aluminium and copper at elevated temperatures using a test known as the Andrade shear test similar to local torsion. The main focus of the work was to define a constitutive description to predict the rupture behaviour of metals under multi-axial loadings and no specific solution was presented for the kinetic or the kinematic behaviour of the test. Similar to the Andrade shear test, the local torsion can be used as a mechanical test which offers some unique features in comparison to the torsion or tensile tests.

In another relevant work, Tóth et al.15 proposed a new SPD process called high-pressure tube twisting (HPTT) which has similarities with local torsion. In HPTT, a tube was expanded from its inside surface by compressing a mandrel placed into the tube and then externally twisted using a disc positioned outside the tube. They used very thin tubes to allow extension of the grain refinement into the whole thickness of the tube. No attempts were made to measure the torque requirement for the process or the torsional strength of the tube. Also, variation in mechanical properties of the processed material was not investigated quantitatively.

A series of investigations were performed on the holding torque calculation of shrink-fitted shaft/hub assemblies which is similar to the local torsion in terms of implementation and loading. There are two major differences between those works and the local torsion. Our finite element (FE) analysis results have indicated that the required torque for the local torsion is higher than the maximum achievable torque by the shrink fit.16 Furthermore, the shrink-fitted shaft/hub assembly remained in the elastic region after applying the torque. Therefore, relationships such as those obtained from Lame’s theory and theory of thick-walled cylinders remained valid and applicable to calculate the holding torque.17 However, during the local torsion process, the specimen deforms plastically and the above mentioned theories may not be used.

In this research, local torsion is considered as a localized SPD process that can take advantage of local grain refinement leading to improvement of mechanical performance within an annular zone around a fastener hole (AZFH). Experimental implementation of local torsion is a challenge since a large torque has to be applied on a cylindrical surface. A successful implementation technique should maintain the required interface conditions between the tool (mandrel) and the specimen and cause minimal geometrical changes to the hole such that the hole can serve its purpose after processing. Thus, for a successful implementation of local torsion, a design analysis should be undertaken to find the best possible interface conditions.

The limited understanding about the mechanics of the local torsion hinders implementation of the process in practice. As a consequence, measuring temporal process parameters at the deformation zone becomes impossible, and therefore, avenues to understand and observe evolution of the process with time are blocked. The scope of this study is to finding a design which allows implementation of the local torsion on a specimen using a mandrel for applying the torque, as shown schematically in Figure 1. This is a pre-requisite to investigate the process experimentally. Figure 1.
Implementing local torsion in practice.

This study deals with the assessment of different possible designs for performing local torsion and sensitivity analysis of affecting parameters. Among the multitude of potential designs to perform the local torsion, only a few of them meet the requirements of a successful design. Finding these designs through laboratory tests and experiments is costly and time consuming. Alternatively, different specimen designs could be assessed numerically in a computer-aided design fashion to understand the requirements of the experiment. The finite element method (FEM) is used to study the requirements of the process and identify the effect of design parameters on the process.

sec.title: Computer-aided specimen design
sec.p:
The process of local torsion can be investigated using a washer type, thin disc-shaped specimen with a central hole to represent the behaviour of a fastener hole in a typical structural component. The required torque to implement the process is estimated by carrying out a series of parametric FE simulations and an optimum geometry is proposed through a numerical design assessment procedure. In the first stage, the torque-carrying capacity of the disc-shaped specimen, shown in Figure 2, was estimated for implementation of the local torsion. The torque-carrying capacity of the specimen defines the maximum amount of torque that the disc specimen can withstand before failure based on the von Mises stress. In the next step of the design, a reinforcement hub is added to the disc specimen to facilitate the application of higher torques to the specimen. Upon successful implementation of the process which causes local grain refinement and consequently a zone with improved mechanical performance, the reinforcing hub will be machined off. The plastically deformed zone with a hole in its middle can then serve as a reinforced fastener hole in any structural application. Figure 2.
Details of preliminary design: disc specimen.

The reinforcement hub requires a proper binding with the mandrel to allow successful transfer of torque to the specimen. Once the torque-carrying capacity of the specimen is known, the design requirements can be explored to assess the critical torque and the role of design parameters on the process. In this article, we systematically alter the geometry of the specimen, fulfilling a set of design requirements in order to find a geometry which can hold the required torque for producing a given value of strain accumulation within the AZFH with a minimum shape change within the reinforcement hub. For this purpose, we analyse the strength of the specimen and the plastic strain field around the hole caused by twisting the specimen on the bore.

sec.title: Plastic strain calculations
sec.p:
For the preliminary design, it is of interest to produce a given amount of plastic shearing strain within the AZFH. In order to achieve an understanding of strain components, their distribution in the specimen and their correlation with the angle of rotation, Φ, a parametric formulation which was proposed in Shamdani and Khoddam18 has been used in an incremental form. When the value of a deformation or strain component is known at a specific step during the solution, an incremental formulation can be applied to the problem to perform the calculations and find the amount of deformation or strain for the next step of solution. As a result of local torsion, the overall deformation of a typical point may be resolved in three components of u,v and w in r, θ and z directions, respectively. During the course of local torsion, the deformation initiates at the surface of the hole and propagates in the r direction in a decaying fashion. Therefore, the displacement boundary conditions can be expressed as a function of angle of rotation (1)u=0 (everywhere in the specimen)
(2)v=riΦ over the entire specimen-mandrel interface
(3)w=0 (everywhere in the specimen)

The deformation zone during the process is highly inaccessible which limits a qualitative measurement on the pattern of deformation. Therefore, numerical methods have been used in this article to study the displacement field via a representative model.18 The assumed displacement model should allow the only non-zero component of the displacement field, v(r,z) , to decay from its maximum value at the edge of the hole where r=ri to its radial minimum at r=ro in the r direction. The model has a non-linear distribution of deformation in the radial direction of the following form which can represent the displacement field in the specimen (4)v(r,z)=riΦexp(A(r-ri)) where A is a constant that depends on specimen geometry and material. Therefore, an incremental displacement field can be proposed by taking the spatial derivative of equation (4) (5)du=0
(6)dv(r,z)={riexp(A(r-ri))}dΦ
(7)dw=0

The components of strain increments can be obtained from the incremental displacement field defined by equations (5) to (7). All components of the strain increments will be zero except dɛrθ , which can be defined as (8)dɛrθ=1rdudθ+dvdr-dvr={(A-1r)riexp(A(r-ri))}dΦ
The increment of equivalent strain is then defined by (9)dɛeq={23riexp(A(r-ri))|A-1r|}dΦ

If parameter A is given, the equivalent strain can be found by integrating the increment of the equivalent strain with respect to the twist angle as follows (10)εeq=∫Φ1Φ2dεeqdΦ=23ri(Φ2−Φ1)exp⁡(A(r−ri))| A−1r | where Φ1 and Φ2 are specified angle of rotations during the local torsion. Equation (10) describes the extent of strain distribution in the radial direction in a qualitative way when the parameter A is known. This parameter and eventually the strain can be found using a range of techniques such as the upper bound method and the FEM, as described in Shamdani and Khoddam.18 In the case of a specimen with a hole of 10 mm in diameter made of Ti-IF (interstitial free) steel, a torque of 119 Nm is required to twist the material around the hole through 55 degrees. In this case, the parameter A is −0.483. Equation (10) then gives an equivalent strain of 3.78 at the edge of the hole.

The plastic shear strain in the region adjacent to the hole can also be calculated using the tangential displacement correlation given in Nordgren and Naghdi11 as follows (11)ɛrθ=M(1+ν)2πr2E-2log(ρ/r)η where r is the distance from centre of the hole, E the Young’s modulus, ν the Poisson’s ratio, η a constant assuming an isotropic hardening behaviour for the material, ρ the radius of elastic–plastic interface (and is equal to M/2πσys ), M the amount of torque per unit thickness and σys the shearing yield stress. Using equation (11), a torque of 119 Nm corresponds to a strain of 3.45 at r = 5 mm (edge of the hole) assuming ν = 0.29, E = 200 GPa, σys = 92 MPa and η = 0.41. With reference to the formulation given in Nordgren and Naghdi11 or the formulation presented here, it can be concluded that a large amount of plastic strain will be induced around the hole as a result of the local torsion processing using equation (10) or (11). Also, a large torque has to be applied in order to accumulate such a large plastic strain around the hole and within the AZFH.

sec.title: A need for specimen reinforcement
sec.p:
Initially, a series of FE simulations was carried out on a specimen, with the following geometrical dimensions: L = 26 mm, dh = 10 mm, ro = 15 mm and ts = 5 mm, to estimate the torque-carrying capacity of the specimen. Details of the FE model including the material and its constitutive model are explained in ‘FE model’ section. The torque required to cause a range of twist angles on the bore of the specimen is shown in Figure 3. As shown in Figure 3, a large torque is required to twist the disc specimen on the bore. Figure 3.
Torque-twist curve of the disc-shaped specimen.

An important parameter for implementation of the local torsion using the preliminary design of the specimen is friction. Assuming a Coulomb friction at the interface, the friction will be directly proportional to the normal pressure between the contacting surfaces. For a given applied torque, the traction forces depend on the contact area. Therefore, a large interactional pressure will be needed to create the required sticking condition between the components for the local torsion. Applying the frictional torque via methods like shrink fit cannot provide the required sticking conditions for implementation of the local torsion. Considering the relatively small dimensions of the hole and the mandrel, the maximum achievable torque with the shrink fit is about 50 Nm which corresponds to only 1° of rotation on the surface of the hole (Figure 3). Therefore, applying torques with the magnitudes given in Figure 3 requires the reinforcement of the specimen. Moreover, by reinforcing the specimen and providing a slippage-free binding, higher amounts of shearing strain can also be accumulated around the surface of the hole.

The geometry of the disc specimen was therefore modified and the central part of the specimen was reinforced by placing a hub on both sides of the disc specimen. The hub allows application of a high torque to the thin and uniform section, ts , of the disc specimen. The ‘reinforced specimen’ is shown in Figure 4 which is identical to the disc specimen but it has a reinforcement segment, a hub, at its centre. The hub’s geometrical parameters include hub thickness, th , hub length, lh , as well as the fillet radius joining the hub and disc together, rhs . Figure 4.
Geometrical parameters of the reinforced specimen.

sec.title: Design assessment
sec.p: Since the mechanics of local torsion is not fully known, assessment of a proposed design is not straightforward and requires numerical modelling. In this study, a computer-aided design of the specimen and sensitivity analysis of design parameters are performed, in which the FE is utilized to analyse the behaviour of the specimen or the specimen–mandrel assembly during local torsion. Once the torque-carrying capacity of the specimen is known, the problem reduces to finding a suitable reinforcement hub for a slippage-free binding between the specimen and the mandrel while the process is completed up to a given angle of rotation. A number of specimen design requirements will be considered here. By checking the fulfilment of these requirements, one can filter improper designs based on different geometrical parameters while comparing different designs.

sec.title: A feasible design
sec.p:
In this study, the effect of the hub’s geometrical parameters and specimen thickness on the torque-carrying capacity of the specimen will be investigated using numerical simulation of the specimen over a given range of rotation angles. In order to reduce the design parameters, the hole diameter and the shape of the external boundary of the specimen are fixed. It is expected that deformation outside the AZFH remains negligible and therefore the extent by which the undeformed part of the specimen extends is not important. A series of analysis–evaluation–modification steps were performed to assess the effect of the geometrical parameters. The design assessment routine is comprised of the following steps.
Selection of the binding type.
Provision of an initial guess for the specimen geometrical parameters.
Calculation of the torque-carrying capacity of the specimen.
Comparison of the torque-carrying capacity with the previous step of solution.
Modifying the geometrical parameters should the comparison requirement fail.
Re-construction of the FE model based on the current geometry should a modified geometry become necessary.
Repeat steps 3–6 until any further change in the specific geometrical parameter has no effects.

The sequence and flow of the operations have been shown in Figure 5 as a flowchart. For a given geometry of the hub, calculation of the torque-carrying capacity in step 3 is directly related to the binding type specified in step 1. Based on a feasible design which is identified by completing steps 1–7, a series of computer-aided sensitivity analyses will be performed to investigate the influence of geometrical parameters on the torque-carrying capacity of the specimen. Figure 5.
Flow chart of specimen design procedure.

sec.p:
In this section, the details of constructing FE models to calculate changes of torque-carrying capacity of the specimen with respect to angle of rotation are discussed. Models for the specimen–mandrel assemblies were developed using Abaqus v6.9.2 software. The von Mises stress was considered to define the maximum allowable torsional load on the specimen. sec.title: Specimen and mandrel modelling
sec.p:
A cross section of the assembly geometry and boundary conditions for FE models are shown in Figure 6. On the mandrel–specimen interface, the tangential and normal contact boundary conditions were specified. Specimen was free to deform on its upper and lower surfaces. The translational degrees of freedom and rotation around the axis of symmetry were restrained on the outer boundary of the specimen. Figure 6.
Boundary conditions imposed on the specimen in the FE models.
FE: finite element.

For the calculation of torque-carrying capacity of the disc-shaped specimen, uniformly distributed torsional loading were applied incrementally over the surface of the hole with a constant density to model the full frictional binding between the mandrel and the specimen. In order to apply the torque, a reference point is considered to which the angular rotation is applied and the corresponding torque is specified indirectly at the interface of the assembly. It should be noted that this is a hypothetical loading case that can be done in practice only if an infinite friction is present at the specimen–mandrel interface. For the selection of the appropriate binding type, surface contact was defined to simulate the contacted region and the interaction between the mandrel and the specimen. The reference point of the mandrel was constrained to rotate solely around the axis of symmetry.

The meshed geometries of the specimens are shown in Figure 7. Because of a substantial deformation gradient in the vicinity of the hole, a finer density of mesh was considered near the hole. The default settings of Abaqus were used to create the sweep mesh. The numbers of the hexahedron (brick) elements used for the hexagon and splined specimens and the tetrahedron elements used for the threaded specimen in the FE models were 5756, 6032 and 7242, respectively. The hexagon, splined and threaded mandrels were meshed with a total number of 453, 452 and 574 quadrilateral elements, respectively. The number of elements and their density as well as the boundary conditions were chosen to secure a rapid convergence in the solution and prevent the rigid body rotation, numerical errors and singularity. Figure 7.
FE models and the meshed geometries of the specimens in Abaqus.
FE: finite element.

For implementation of the local torsion, one has to ensure that the mandrel remains rigid during the process. Therefore, material selection for the mandrel deserves a careful study in order to prevent mandrel fracture or excessive deformation during the process. Separate strength analyses for the mandrel were performed to ensure the validity of assuming a rigid mandrel. The validity of this assumption depends on the ratio of the mandrel’s torsional stiffness to that of the specimen and also to the extent by which the mandrel rotates before the onset of slippage at the mandrel–specimen interface.

sec.title: Material properties
sec.p: A key factor for a successful local torsion is the cold formability and the plastic behaviour of the material. In the FE models, a Ti-IF steel was chosen for the study. Yield strength, modulus of elasticity and Poisson’s ratio of this material at room temperature were considered 235 MPa, 200 GPa and 0.29, respectively. This steel has an excellent cold formability which makes it a good candidate for local torsion.

In order to create an accurate simulation, a precise representation of material behaviour is needed. The specimen is subjected to large amounts of shearing strain within the AZFH. Due to the shearing nature of the deformation, a torsion test cannot adequately represent the behaviour of material subjected to local torsion. On the other hand, similar deformation mechanisms in the torsion test and local torsion makes a torsion test a more reliable method for defining material behaviour. A torsion test can also represent material behaviour over an extensive range of deformation. As a result, the constitutive model to be used in the FEM analyses was constructed using the torque-twist data obtained from the torsion test. The flow curve of the Ti-IF steel was obtained by conducting torsion tests using an in-house torsion testing machine designed and manufactured in the authors’ research laboratory. The cylindrical torsion test samples used are shown in Figure 8. The torsion tests and the specimen design were performed according to the ASTM E143-02 designation, standard test method for shear modulus at room temperature. The torsion tests were conducted with a rotation rate of 2.2 × 10−3 s−1. The hardening behaviour of Ti-IF steel was constructed using the experimental data points and a power function fit in the form of σ=Kɛn , with its parameters K = 518 MPa and n = 0.178. The R2 value of the fitted curve was 0.9617, as shown in Figure 9. For conversion of torque-twist data to the effective stress–strain, the methods described in Khoddam and Hodgson19,20 were used. Figure 8.
Torsion test specimen, dimensions are in mm.
Figure 9.
True stress–strain curve of IF steel obtained from the torsion test.
IF: interstitial free.

sec.title: Selection of the binding type
sec.p: To identify the feasible specimen design and keep the sticking condition between the mandrel and specimen, three binding types of the assembly were considered. With these three binding types, the interlocking condition in the specimen–mandrel assembly could be maintained firmly, resulting in accumulation of strain around the fastener hole. These binding types are: prismatic hexagon, prismatic splined and threaded. They will be studied and compared in the following sections to assess their feasibility for implementation of the local torsion.

The first binding type investigated was the prismatic hexagon joint at the interface. The schematic of specimen and mandrel for the joint is shown in Figure 10(a). FE simulation of the hexagon assembly showed that rotation of the mandrel expands the hub in the radial direction. Consequently, pure local torsion condition will be violated, leading to a combined loading state. This is a violation of the fifth design criterion defined in ‘A feasible design’ section. The hexagon configuration caused excessive distortion in the hub (violation of the fourth design criterion) and appeared to be unusable and hence discarded from any following investigations. The deformed shape of the specimen after 60° of mandrel rotation is shown in Figure 11(a). It can be seen that this binding type is not capable of inducing adequate and uniform plastic deformation around the hole. Figure 10.
Schematic view of three different binding-type configurations including specimen and its corresponding mandrel: (a) hexagon; (b) splined; and (c) threaded.
Figure 11.
Equivalent plastic strain contours on the deformed shape of the specimen: (a) hexagon; (b) splined; and (c) threaded.

Another binding type examined was the prismatic splined joint. The schematic of specimen and mandrel for this type are shown in Figure 10(b). Similar to the hexagon assembly, considerable shape changes occurred in the hub during the process (violation of the fourth design criterion), and therefore, this binding type was considered impractical and excluded from any further studies. Figure 11(b) illustrates the deformed splined specimen after 60° of mandrel rotation which led to a considerable deformation of the hub section.

The third binding type studied was the threaded joint. In this configuration, the mating faces of mandrel and hole were threaded and tapped, respectively, as shown in Figure 10(c). For the threaded assembly, the maximum allowable holding torque (torque-carrying capacity) of a threaded connection with the specified dimensions was calculated according to the thread strength calculations standard,21 and then torsional loads up to the maximum allowable torques were applied to the specimen to reach specified angular rotations. Unlike the other configurations, threaded configuration reserved the pure torsional nature of loading without any noticeable changes in the geometry (Figure 11(c)).

The torsional behaviour of specimen with the reinforcing hub under three different binding types is compared in Figure 12 which shows that the torque-carrying capacity of the threaded assembly is higher compared to the other two binding types. Investigating the three different binding types, one can see that for the specified material and specimen geometry, the only possible feasible option is the threaded binding. Therefore, the threaded assembly was considered as the feasible design by meeting all the design criteria mentioned in ‘A feasible design’ section. Figure 12.
Torque-twist curve comparison for threaded, splined and hexagon specimens.

sec.title: Sensitivity analysis for the parameters of the feasible design
sec.p: Considering the threaded joint as the feasible binding type, a sensitivity analysis of individual geometrical parameters of the specimen is performed in this section. The main objective of the sensitivity analysis is to change the geometrical parameters of the hub such that the major flow localization concentrates outside of the hub and on the body of the specimen. Therefore, more plastic deformation can be induced in the vicinity of the hole surface and with a smaller torque. It is preferable to induce plastic deformation within the AZFH by smaller magnitudes of torque. In this study, all analytical solutions were presented for a particular size of the hole ( dh = 10 mm). While the effect of each geometrical parameter is being investigated throughout this section, only one parameter changes at a time. The optimum values obtained for geometrical parameters from previous design steps are being used for the current design step.

sec.title: Effect of specimen thickness, ts
sec.p:
The effect of changes in specimen thickness on the torque-carrying capacity of the reinforced disc specimen is investigated here. The sensitivity study of the specimen thickness included a range of 2–5 mm to investigate the thickness effect. To study the effect of specimen thickness on torque-carrying capacity of the specimen, torque-twist curves of the reinforced disc specimen with thicknesses of 2, 3, and 5 mm are compared together in Figure 13. The reduction in the thickness of the specimen reduces the resistance of the material to the plastic deformation and facilitates the accumulation of a larger strain within the interested zone. Figure 13.
Effect of specimen thickness on its torque-carrying capacity.

By decreasing the thickness of the specimen deformation could be concentrated around the fastener hole with a much smaller torque. Reduction in thickness also improved the formability of the specimen subjected to local torsion such that greater rotational displacements could be applied to the specimen. The reduction of the specimen thickness to less than 2 mm was undesirable as it could cause bending of the specimen during loading and unloading of the sample into the test rig due to excessive thickness and strength reduction. It was anticipated that increasing the thickness of the specimen increases the required torque to internally twist the specimen for a specified angle of rotation which was accordingly confirmed with FE simulations.

sec.title: Effect of hub length, lh
sec.p:
In the next stage of the sensitivity analysis, effects of the reinforcing hub length on torque-carrying capacity of the specimen were investigated. Using an optimum thickness of 2 mm for the specimen, the length of the hub was decreased gradually from 5 to 2 mm. Figure 14 shows the effect of hub length reduction on torque-carrying capacity of the specimen. The reduction in the hub length reduces the effective length over which a slippage-free binding exists at the specimen–mandrel interface. A smaller binding surface puts a constraint on the maximum plastic deformation and twisting which can be applied to the specimen. Figure 14.
Effect of hub length on specimens’ torque-carrying capacity.

It was observed that reduction of the reinforcing hub length decreases the torque-carrying capacity of the specimen. Hub length reduction decreases the formability of the specimen and allows less twisting to be applied before the specimen reaches the fracture point. Further reduction of the hub length to less than 2 mm was not practicable due to the presence of the fillet at the adjoining section of the specimen and the reinforcing hub. On the other hand, any increase in the hub length culminated in a higher torque-carrying capacity of the specimen according to FE simulations which was not favourable for the purpose of the local torsion implementation.

sec.title: Effect of hub thickness, th
sec.p:
The next sensitivity analysis was performed for the hub thickness which was increased from 1 to 2 mm, with optimum values of ts = 2 mm and lh = 2 mm, to study the subsequent critical torque changes. The effect of hub thickness on the torque-carrying capacity of the specimen is shown in Figure 15. Changing the thickness of the hub affects its rigidity and strength while it is subjected to a torsional loading from inside. Numerical results showed that the torque-carrying capacity of the specimen rises as the thickness of the hub increases. Moreover, the specimen showed more formability with a thicker hub. Figure 15.
Effect of hub thickness on specimens’ torque-carrying capacity.

The increase in the torque-carrying capacity implies that for a given angle of rotation, a higher torque is needed to twist the specimen on the bore. This behaviour is not desirable for implementation of the process. Therefore, hub thickness reduction is preferable as it leads to a lower torque-carrying capacity and less required torque for a specified angle of rotation. However, decreasing the hub thickness to less than 1 mm could culminate in an excessively weak hub. For this reason, the thickness of the hub remained fixed as 1 mm.

sec.title: Effect of hub/specimen fillet radius, rhs
sec.p:
The last part of the sensitivity analysis included the effect of hub/specimen fillet radius. A range of 0.3–1 mm, with the optimum values of ts = 2 mm, lh = 2 mm and th = 1 mm, was considered for studying the changes in torque-carrying capacity. The comparison of the results is shown in Figure 16. The size of the fillet plays an important role in the accumulation of the shearing strain around the hole. The hub/specimen fillet is the location of the maximum strain concentration and the transfer of deformation from the hub to the specimen. FE simulation results showed that the torque-carrying capacity of the specimen dropped as the radius of hub/specimen fillet was decreased. As a result, lower torques can be applied to twist the specimen on the bore over a wider range of angle of rotations in comparison with a specimen of larger fillet radius (a delayed failure). Hence, the optimum value of 0.3 mm was chosen. Further reduction to the fillet radius was infeasible due to manufacturing limitations on creating a fillet with smaller radius. Hence, the optimum value of 0.3 mm was chosen as the best possible radius for the hub/specimen fillet size. Figure 16.
Effect of hub/specimen fillet radius on specimens’ torque-carrying capacity.

Subsequently, an optimum specimen with ts = 2 mm, lh = 2 mm and th = 1 mm and rhs = 0.3 mm was considered for a closer study of the local torsion process parameters using the threaded binding. Accumulated deformation in the AZFH of the optimum specimen will be investigated in the following section.

sec.title: Accumulated plastic strain
sec.p:
FE simulations of the optimum specimen were performed for different angle of rotations starting from 10 with increments of 15 up to 70° for threaded binding. Equivalent plastic strain distributions from the edge of the hole to the external edge as well as the tangential displacement in the same direction are shown in Figures 17 and 18. The strain values were picked from the nodes using the contour plots. As shown in Figures 17 and 18, using the threaded binding, one can effectively implement the process of local torsion and induce high plastic strains around the fastener hole. Choosing a threaded joint, one may obtain an equivalent plastic strain of about 1.6 for the maximum allowable rotation. Figure 17.
Equivalent plastic strain for threaded specimen at various angle of rotations.
Figure 18.
Tangential displacement variation for threaded specimen at various angle of rotations.

The maximum plastic strain occurs where the reinforcing hub joins the body of the specimen and that is where the final reamed fastener hole is located. The adjoining hub/specimen section is where the maximum stress concentration and consequently maximum strain accumulation is happening. This section is the weakest part on the specimen and that is why the maximum strain occurs at this point and not at the point of maximum displacement. In other words, the strength of the hub is higher than the hub/specimen joining section and the hub as a more rigid part transfers the displacement to the joining section and the body of the specimen.

sec.title: Experimental test
sec.p: Experiments were performed by producing the specimens with the geometry according to the optimum design which was obtained through the sensitivity analysis. For implementation of the local torsion process using the threaded assembly, the mandrel and the specimen were manufactured according to the design shown in Figure 10(c). The torque is applied to the stepped-threaded mandrel until it is fully tightened inside the tapped reinforcement hub. As the torque continues to be applied, the mandrel shoulder which is in contact with the hub edge prevents mandrel penetration into the hole.

Visual inspection of the specimen after processing revealed the localized characteristic of the process adjacent to the surface of the hole. The surface of the sample was gridded and the grids in the vicinity of the hole were measured after the sample deformed to failure. As shown in Figure 19(a), the initially radial grids on the specimen were distorted after deformation up to a certain distance from the edge of the hole where the surface of the specimen became irregular and non-reflective. The extent of plastic deformation and flow localization zone was found to be limited in the radial direction. Figure 19.
Deformation of specimen after local torsion processing: (a) top view of the specimen with distorted grids and (b) optical micrograph of the deformed specimen.

Optical microscopy of the processed specimens was also used to study the nature and extent of deformation induced by the local torsion process. The micrograph in Figure 19(b) depicts an area at the border of AZFH in which both deformed and undeformed zones are visible. As shown in this figure, the material adjacent to the hole surface has been heavily deformed in a pure shearing deformation mode, leading to elongated grains. By moving further away from the hole surface in the radial direction, shape of the grains changes. The gradient of mechanical properties is advantageous from the viewpoint of localized strengthening of materials in the areas of interest. Due to the small thickness of the specimen used in experiments, gradients of grain refinement along the thickness of the specimen were negligible. Further details of the microstructural investigations and improvements on material’s performance can be found in Shamdani et al.9

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A design assessment procedure was adopted on the geometry of a local torsion specimen to find the practical configurations to implement the process using a mandrel–specimen assembly. The process was aimed at creating large magnitudes of plastic deformation and strain within the AZFH which could consequently result in local grain refinement of the material and a likely improvement of material’s mechanical properties. Placing a reinforcing hub could increase the torque-carrying capacity of the fastener hole. Reduction in the thickness of the specimen provided more formability for implementation of local torsion. Three specimen–mandrel assembly configurations, hexagonal, splined and threaded, were proposed for implementation of the process. The threaded assembly showed promising results for implementation of the local torsion, while the hexagon and splined joints did not fulfil the design requirements.

In order to obtain an optimum geometry of the mandrel/specimen interface for successful implementation of the local torsion, the thickness of the specimen was reduced. Reduction in the hub length as well as the hub/specimen fillet radius decreased the torque-carrying capacity of the specimen, while the increase in the hub thickness raised the torque required to twist the specimen to a given angle of rotation. The elongated and refined grains within the AZFH as an experimental observation of the local torsion confirmed the usefulness of the specimen design procedure adopted in this study. It was shown that the reinforced specimen with a threaded binding is capable of producing large shearing strains and plastic deformation in the material around the hole leading to the grain refinement.
